{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3375800,"name":"Luis Mota","username":"DonMota_88","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/donmota_88/{size}/207079_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T05:06:36.659Z","cooked":"

During my time on FRC I’ve seen the importance of having almost no backlash on your robots mecanisms, as it could be a shooter or an intake, being this of high importance for precision or even for the protection of robot parts.

I tried to find information about it on CD but I think it’s all spread out on different build threads, so I was wondering, what do top teams do for preventing backlash on their robots.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T05:06:36.659Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":313,"reads":653,"readers_count":652,"score":1745.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":464782,"topic_slug":"ways-to-prevent-backlash","display_username":"Luis Mota","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55346,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7102 Team captain Mec/CAD | 26376 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/ways-to-prevent-backlash/464782/1","custom_user_title":"7102 Team captain Mec/CAD | 26376 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3375804,"name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","username":"Knufire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T05:18:04.866Z","cooked":"

The hex interface on most common FRC components is a big contributing factor to backlash, as FRC hex shaft usually runs a few thou undersized while the bores run a few thou over. Using shim tape to tighten up this interface is the bulk of it.

Team 4414 | HighTide | 2023 Robot: Tsunami Robot Showcase
Here’s some photos showing the shimming process: [image] [image] [image] [image] [image]
mcmaster.com

McMaster-Carr

McMaster-Carr is the complete source for your plant with over 595,000 products. 98% of products ordered ship from stock and deliver same or next day.

Putting some counterbalancing spring force on an arm can also serve dual purpose of reducing the effective weight you’re moving and ensuring that the mechanism is always preloaded against one side of your backlash. Gas shocks for this purpose seem to be getting more popular every year.

We found handling backlash was crucial this year. Added a ton of consistency to our shots, and improved effective range considerably.

We just added a quick routine that preceded autos, which:

  • Make sure the absolute encoder status frames are being reported rapidly (applies to CAN encoders)
  • apply enough motor power to tense the system in the normal operating direction
  • Wait 0.1s (~10 encoder status frames, and according to velocity graphs, just enough time to stabilize mechanically)
  • Re-assert our angle on our motor encoder.
  • Resume operation.

Full code is here, if it’s of interest. https://github.com/stormbots/Crescendo/blob/comp/champs/src/main/java/frc/robot/commands/CalibrateShooter.java

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T06:10:38.603Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":571,"readers_count":570,"score":139.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464782,"topic_slug":"ways-to-prevent-backlash","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12760,"username":"Knufire","name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/ways-to-prevent-backlash/464782/3","custom_user_title":"2811 Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3375821,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T06:45:05.165Z","cooked":"

For backlash-sensitive mechanisms:

  • Avoid hex-hex interfaces entirely if possible, and shim them if they are unavoidable. Hex-hex interfaces are generally one of the worst sources of backlash and can wear out making the already bad backlash even worse.
  • Clamping mounts have 0 backlash. Even if they are hex-hex clamping mounts.
  • Tension belts. While they don’t need tension to run, adding extra tension takes up the backlash. Eccentric bolt patterns are a nice option here as they don’t come with the downsides of idlers.
  • Avoid small pulleys and sprockets
  • Drive arms and hoods from the outside rather than at the pivot point. Driving arms from far away reduces the impact that backlash has on the final angular displacement.
  • Custom gearboxes with fewer shimmed stages will have less backlash than maxplanetaries with similar reductions.
  • Tolerances matter when dealing with fits. If you are dealing with any sort of fitment, its worth spending the extra few minutes to make the part to 1thou instead of 5thou.
  • Watch out for general stiffness issues too. Eliminating backlash with all of the above doesn’t matter if your mechanism is made of polycarb or not stiff in some other way and will move around anyways.
  • Only use counterspringing as a method of backlash compensation as a last-resort. While at rest it may work, the dynamic loads of many systems are much greater than gravity or the counterspringing is and you will still run into control problems.

For mechanism not that sensitive to backlash, most of the above is likely unnecessary, however, shim tape is still your friend and don’t drive things from the center if at all possible.

What are these eccentric bolt patterns you speak of? They sound useful

Green loctite can do a good job removing backlash on a shaft. Just make sure to match the loctite’s gap size to your actual gap size.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T13:36:07.540Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":12,"reads":388,"readers_count":387,"score":172.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":464782,"topic_slug":"ways-to-prevent-backlash","display_username":"Alexander Kaplan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14606,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6377 mentor, 401 advice giver"},"post_url":"/t/ways-to-prevent-backlash/464782/6","custom_user_title":"6377 mentor, 401 advice giver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3375893,"name":"Adam Fleming","username":"AdamF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adamf/{size}/234717_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T14:17:07.825Z","cooked":"

Just make sure it’s not something you need to take off to make repairs. On a 1/2 in hex, that sucker isn’t coming off without some brute force and/or heat.

image1576×1237 157 KB

Take a bolt pattern and make several copies of it with each successive pattern shifted over and rotated. To tension your mechanism, just use a different set of holes.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T17:08:10.834Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":309,"readers_count":308,"score":156.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464782,"topic_slug":"ways-to-prevent-backlash","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/4/1/417ab2854becfe3817352566306922a5e34ee1ce.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":60691,"username":"widekarl","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/widekarl/{size}/201391_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/ways-to-prevent-backlash/464782/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3376001,"name":"","username":"AVHon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T17:45:08.357Z","cooked":"

Just to elaborate a little: the shifting is to give you a choice of fits. The rotating is just to allow the holes to not all intersect with each other. The pictured example is a 4-hole pattern with 7 different offsets which vary the center location left-right.
